prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information in Historical Context

para.paratext: The large corporations of the Industrial Age created the need for communication over long distances, data storage and increased competition, which in turn fueled the Information Age. In post-industrial society, information, more than labour, land or concrete inventions, has become the basis of wealth. Information is a combination of equipment and techniques and the know-how of those who develop them. New information is created at ever-increasing speeds as a result of new technologies such as microprocessing, fibre optics, lenses and digitization. In 1956, white-collar workers, that is, those in technical, managerial and clerical positions, outnumbered blue-collar workers for the first time in modern history. In 1982, more than 60% of American jobs were information-handling jobs, compared to only 13% manufacturing jobs. In many cases, there is no longer any physical property to protect, and the significance of information often lies in the exploitation of an idea rather than physical access to it.[1]
G. Klueck, “The Coming Jurisprudence of the Information Age: Examinations of the Three Past Socio-Economic Ages Suggest the Future” (1984), 21 San Diego L. Rev. 1077 at p. 1079.
